When a small group of living beings (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it originated (for example, if it moves over a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return), it often finds itself in a different environment than the one it was in before.
This new environment has different resources and competitors, so the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations to be a powerful competitor compared to what it needed before.
The population of origin has not changed at all, they still need the same adaptations.
Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to look less and less like the other population.
Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they will no longer be considered to belong to the same species.
We call this process "speciation", which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and an important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense in which the destiny of humanity is dictated by an underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technologies.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: the development of technology itself proceeds beyond the influence of cultural and political factors, and technology has an impact on societies conditioned intrinsically rather than socially.
For example, we could say that the automobile necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a handful of cars, which is why new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of owning a car.
Massive car ownership also leads to a greater incidence of accidents on the roads, which leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to treat the resulting injuries.

Two years after the end of the war, the former allies became enemies and the Cold War began.
It would last for the next 40 years and would see real battles, through proxy armies, on battlefields in Africa and Asia, in Afghanistan, Cuba, and many other places.

Using ships to transport cargo is by far the most efficient way to move large quantities of people and goods across the oceans.

The work of the Navy has traditionally been to ensure that your country maintains the ability to move your people and your goods, while interfering with your enemy's ability to move his people and his goods.

One of the most remarkable examples of this situation was the North Atlantic Campaign during World War II. The Americans were trying to get soldiers and supplies across the Atlantic Ocean to help Great Britain.
At the same time, the German navy, using mainly U-Boats, was trying to stop this traffic.
If the Allies had failed, Germany would probably have conquered Britain as it did the rest of Europe.
It seems that goats were domesticated for the first time about 10,000 years ago in the Zagros Mountains of Iran.
Ancient cultures and tribes began to keep them near them to have easy access to milk, hair, meat and skins.

Domestic goats were usually kept in herds that roamed the hills or other grazing areas, often cared for by shepherds who were usually children or adolescents, similar to the more common term of shepherds. These pastoral methods are still in use today.
Wagonways were built in England in the 16th century.

Although the wagon ways were simply made of parallel planks of wood, they allowed the horses that pulled them to reach greater speeds and to pull heavier loads than on the slightly more accident-prone roads of the day.
The cruisers were introduced quite early to keep the tracks in place. However, it was soon realized that the tracks would be more effective if they were fitted with a metal strip on top.
It has become a common practice, but iron wheels caused more wear on wooden wagon wheels.
Finally, wooden wheels were replaced by iron wheels. In 1767, the first iron rails appeared.

Their predecessors, the australopiths, did not walk upright as usual.
Bipedal specializations are found in Australopithecus fossils dating from 4.2 to 3.9 million years ago, although Sahelanthropus may have walked on two legs as early as seven million years ago.

After its adoption by the Congress on the 4th of July, a handwritten manuscript signed by the President of the Congress John Hancock and the Secretary Charles Thomson was then sent to a few streets away, to the printing house of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, today known as Dunlap Broadsides.
The first public reading of the document was made by John Nixon in the Independence Hall courtroom on July 8.
One of them was sent to George Washington on July 6, who read it to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy reached London on August 10.
The 25 Dunlap copies that we know of are the oldest surviving copies of the document. The original manuscript has not survived.

Periodic rhythms, which are not simply responses to periodic external stimuli, have been documented for most living things, including bacteria, fungi, plants and animals.
Biological clocks are self-sufficient oscillators that will continue to function for a certain period of time, even in the absence of external stimulation.

Hershey and Chase used phages, or viruses, to implant their own DNA into a bacterium.

In this dynamic transport shuttle, everyone is in some way connected to a transport system based on private cars and supports it.

Traffic flow is the study of the movements of drivers and individual vehicles between two points, and the interactions they have with each other.
Unfortunately, it is difficult to study traffic flow because the behaviour of drivers cannot be predicted with 100% certainty.
Fortunately, drivers tend to act in a reasonable range; thus, traffic flows tend to have a reasonable coherence and can be mathematically approximated.
To better represent traffic flow, relationships have been established between the three main characteristics: (1) the flow rate, (2) the density, and (3) the speed.
These relations help with planning, design and operation of road facilities.
Insects were the first animals to fly. Their ability to fly allowed them to escape their enemies more easily and to find food and mates more efficiently.
Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings along their body.
It gives them more places to hide from predators.
Today, the only insects that can't fold their wings are dragonflies and mayflies.

The Amazon is the second-longest and largest river in the world. It carries eight times the volume of water of the second-largest river.
The Amazon is also the largest river in the world, sometimes reaching 10 km in width.
At least 20% of the water that flows from the rivers of the planet into the oceans comes from the Amazon.

Content theories focus on what makes people feel good or what attracts them.

At the other end of the spectrum, one transforms into an unrecognizable individual who feels that he/she must change everything that the group has created so far and do things their way.

Virtual teams are subject to the same standards of excellence as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences.
Members of a virtual team often function as a point of contact for their immediate physical group.
They often have more autonomy than traditional team members because their teams can meet according to different time zones, which may not be understood by their local management.
The presence of a real "invisible team" (Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109) is also a unique element of a virtual team.
The 'invisible team' is the team of management to which each member reports. It sets the standards for each of them.

Field trips are an integral part of any school class. Often, a teacher would like to take his or her students to places where a bus trip is not possible.

The solution is provided by technology in the form of virtual field trips. Students can look at ancient artifacts in a museum, visit an aquarium, or admire a beautiful work of art while sitting with their class.
Taking part in a practical excursion is also a great way to reflect on a trip and share your experiences with future generations.

For example, students from Bennet High School in North Carolina design a website each year about their visit to the state capital. Each year, the site is updated, but the old versions are kept online to serve as an album.

Blogs can also help students to improve their writing skills. Even though students often try blogging with a careless grammar and spelling, the fact that they have an audience generally improves the situation.
As students are often the most critical audience, the blog author begins to strive to improve his writing to avoid criticism.
In addition, blogging "requires students to better know the world around them". The need to attract the attention of the public encourages students to be intelligent and interesting (Toto, 2004).
Blogs are a tool that stimulates collaboration and encourages students to extend their learning beyond the traditional school day.

"When used properly, blogs "can help students strengthen their analytical and critical thinking skills: by reacting actively to online content, they can confront their opinions with those of others and expose their own points of view on well-defined topics" (Oravec, 2002)."

The modern city of Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 10th century BC, and was used by the Phoenicians, the Romans and the Merinides as a strategic port called Anfa.
The Portuguese, who had destroyed it and then rebuilt and renamed it Casa Branca, finally abandoned it in 1755 after an earthquake.
The Moroccan sultan rebuilt the city under the name Daru l-Badya, and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places in all of Morocco for shopping.

Around the old medina, it is easy to find places where you can buy traditional Moroccan products, such as tagines, pottery, leather goods, hookahs and all sorts of souvenirs, but that's all for tourists.
Goma is a tourist town in the extreme east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, near Rwanda.
In 2002, Goma was destroyed by the lava of the Nyiragongo volcano which buried most of the streets of the city, in particular the city centre.
Although Goma is relatively safe, any visit outside Goma should be subject to research to understand the state of the fighting that continues in the North Kivu province.
The city is also the starting point for the ascent of the volcano Nyiragongo as well as for treks of gorilla tracking among the cheapest in Africa.
You can use boda-boda (motorcycle taxi) to move around in Goma. The normal (local) price is about 500 Congolese francs for a short ride.
Combined with its relative inaccessibility, "Timbuktu" has become a metaphor for distant and exotic countries.

It was one of the main steps of the PBS show "Wonders of the African World" by Henry Louis Gates.

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in the northeast of South Africa and borders the Mozambique border to the east, the Zimbabwe border to the north and the Crocodile River to the south.
The total surface area of the park is 19,500 km2, which is divided into 14 ecozones, each of which has its own unique fauna.
It is one of the best known theme parks in South Africa and is considered the jewel in the crown of South African National Parks (SANParks).
As with all South African national parks, there are daily entrance and conservation fees for the park.
It may be advantageous to buy a Wild Card which gives access to some parks in South Africa, as well as to all South African national parks.
Hong Kong Island gives its name to the territory of Hong Kong and represents the main attraction for many tourists.

The vast majority of urban development on Hong Kong Island is concentrated on the reclaimed land on the northern shore.

The Sundarbans are the largest coastal mangrove forest in the world, stretching 80 kilometres (50 miles) from the coast to the hinterland of Bangladesh and India.
The Sundarbans have been declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO. The part of the forest located on Indian territory is called Sundarbans National Park.
Forests are not composed only of mangrove swamps: they also contain some of the last remnants of the majestic jungles that once covered the Ganges plain.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 square kilometres (1,500 sq mi), of which about a third is covered by water/marshes.
Sundarbans is a nature reserve since 1966, you can find there about 400 Bengal tigers and 30,000 spotted deer.

The Oyapock Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge. It spans the Oyapock River to link the towns of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges-de-l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
The two towers rise to a height of 83 metres; it is 378 metres long and has two lanes 3.5 metres wide.
The vertical clearance under the bridge is 15 metres. The structure was completed in August 2011, but it was not opened to traffic until March 2017.
The bridge should be fully operational by September 2017, when the Brazilian customs posts should be completed.
The Guaraní were the largest indigenous group inhabiting what is now the eastern part of Paraguay, living as semi-nomadic hunter-gatherers and practicing subsistence agriculture.
Other indigenous tribes that populated the Chaco, such as the Guaycurú or the Payaguá, survived mainly thanks to fishing, hunting or gathering.
In the 16th century, Paraguay, formerly known as the ‘giant province of the Indies’, was born from the encounter between Spanish conquerors and indigenous populations.
The Spaniards inaugurated the period of colonization, which lasted three centuries.
Since the foundation of Asuncion in 1537, Paraguay has managed to preserve a large part of its indigenous character and identity.

The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Islands pound (FKP), whose value is equivalent to one British pound (GBP).
Money can be exchanged at the only bank in the islands, located in Stanley, opposite the FIC West store.
The pound sterling is a commonly accepted currency throughout the islands, while at Stanley, credit cards and U.S. dollars are also often accepted.
On nearby islands, credit cards are unlikely to be accepted, even if it is possible that British and American currencies will be. Speak to the owners in advance to agree on a payment method.
It is almost impossible to exchange money from the Falkland Islands outside the islands, so change it before leaving the islands.

The stirrups are supports for the rider's feet, which hang on either side of the saddle.
